issue.title: Make it possible to write Bears in Haskell
issue.body:
It would be nice if coala would support bears written in Haskell. I have an example bear at https://github.com/maweki/coalaCheckBear-hs and a haskell framework prototype at https://github.com/maweki/coalaHs. As discussed with @sils, you guys could help out with the python/coala-side templating while I do the Haskell stuff.
Currently the example bear could be run with (if stack is set up) stack build && cat in.example.json | stack exec coalaCheckBear-hs. stack build can be run by coala and the files the bear registered for can be piped into stack exec coalaCheckBear-hs
I think for this use case it is enough that the bear is self-contained. Any user interaction can be handled from the python side but the haskell-bear is basically a function from a stdin json to a stdout json where IO might be allowed.
As a base of discussion I'd consider a haskell-based bear one of the following two types: coala :: String -> (ByteString -> Maybe a) -> (a -> [Result]) -> IO () or coalaIO :: String -> (ByteString -> Maybe a) -> (a -> IO [Result]) -> IO () where the do-Nothing implementation of a full bear would be main = coala "doNothingBear" singleFile (const []).

issue.title: Extend exception message test regex in LinterTest.py

'[A-Za-z_]+ must be an instance of type [A-Za-z_]+'

Otherwise people who read the string
'[a-z_]+ must be an instance'

(As seen the regex shall also support upper-case letters for the variable name, as python variable names don't have to be lower-case only.)

issue.title: IgnoreResultAction.py: Can use multiline_comment_delimiter as a fallback when comment_delimiter doesn't exist for a language
issue.body:
Initial discussion
Presently IgnoreResultAction.py uses comment_delimiter attribute to add ignore comments.
Some bears such as CSSLintBear have multiline_comment_delimiter attribute and not a comment_delimiter and therefore this causes failure to add ignore comment in css files.
Steps for reproduction:

Create file style.css

.low{
font-family:Roboto;
color:white;
}



Execute coala --bears CSSLintBear --files style.css

style.css
|   1| .low•{
|    | [NORMAL] CSSLintBear:
|    | Rule doesn't have all its properties in alphabetical order. (order-alphabetical)
|    | *0: Do nothing
|    |  1: Open file(s)
|    |  2: Add ignore comment
|    | Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): 2
|    | Please enter a value for the parameter 'language' (No description given.): css
[ERROR][14:26:06] Failed to execute the action IgnoreResultAction with error: 'comment_delimiter'.
|    | *0: Do nothing
|    |  1: Open file(s)
|    |  2: Add ignore comment
|    | Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): 2
|    | Please enter a value for the parameter 'language' (No description given.): css
[ERROR][14:26:13] Failed to execute the action IgnoreResultAction with error: 'comment_delimiter'.
|    | *0: Do nothing
|    |  1: Open file(s)
|    |  2: Add ignore comment
|    | Enter number (Ctrl-D to exit): 2
|    | Please enter a value for the parameter 'language' (No description given.): scss
[ERROR][14:26:19] Failed to execute the action IgnoreResultAction with error: .

It is asking for the parameter 'language' from the user and then if there is no language found with name css, it returns
Failed to execute the action IgnoreResultAction with error: 'comment_delimiter'.

Possible Solution
We can add an option in IgnoreResultAction,
 if language has attribute comment delimiter then
    use comment_delimiter to add ignore comment
 elif language.hasattr(multiline_comment_delimiter) and not language.hasattr(comment_delimiter):
   use multilime_comment_delimiter to add ignore comment
else
  print ("We don't have a comment_delimiter for this language, What would you like to wrap the ignore comment in ?")
   take comment delimiter as an input from user

issue.title: Investigate piton support
issue.body:
piton works like npm.  It doesnt install the requirements globally, or create a venv, but has a local .python_modules which needs to be added to the PYTHONPATH.  This would mostly be useful for developer environments.
The piton package.json can be generated by .ci/generate_bear_requirements.py, and coala should be able to find the .python_modules, and add it to the module loader path at runtime.
Initially this issue is primarily to describe how piton could work in practise for coala, noting any blockers.
Opened via gitter by @jayvdb

issue.title: Provide a collection of fully ready-to-use .coafile, for popular languages?
issue.body:
Hi,
That's not an issue, it's more like a feature proposal.
Issue
All the documentation about coala and .coafiles is great, but I think it misses a very important aspect: examples.
And I am not talking about a 5-lines example of a .coafile configured for just one CoalaBear.
I am talking about full examples for one (or more) language.
For instance for Python 3, there is about a dozen of different Bears (+ the generic ones), and it just feels that it would take a few hours to read all their doc, understand and tune all their settings, and write the "perfect" .coafile -- at least for new users of coala, maybe experts can do that quickly (I can't).
Example
Is there any repository that contain a collection of ready-to-use .coafile  for the most popular languages? (I was unable to find any)
For instance, GitHub has this well known repository for .gitignore files (@github/gitignore), with one or more examples of complete and ready-to-use files for some languages. Same is true for all the "dotfiles" repo that some GitHub users keep.
Proposal
So my proposal & request is to start the same project for .coafile.  It could be named @coala/coafile-examples, or something like this.
Why?
The main reason for this list of "ready-to-use" examples is to increase the pace at which new coala users can indeed use coala "in production".
When using a provided examples, it gives a ground base from where to start, instead of having to write the config file from scratch.
(Disclaimer: I do not offer to solve it, I am basically asking this as I cannot figure how to quickly write a good .coafile for my dev workflow)

issue.title: Replace pkg_resources with implicit namespace packages
issue.body:
pkg_resources breaks in an unrecoverable/unmanagable way when there is a VersionConflict.
If we empty out the root namespace of bears (blocked by coala/coala-bears#1199), we can use implicit namespace packages (PEP 420), which allows us to iterate over the subpackages of the namespace bears, and also allows the namespace bears to be filled by multiple pypi distribution packages. e.g. pypi 'coala-bears-python' could provide bears/python/.

issue.title: derpecate_settings: Allow modifying the new param if both new param and old param are provided
issue.body:
Current implementation will use new param, if both new and old param is provided. But it may be useful to use the old setting and modify the new setting accordingly and make the new setting more flexible by allowing it to be modified.
Example:
In coala/coala-bears#1244

We changed a setting from an int to a dict.
What I'd like to do is:
1. See if timeout setting is set, lets say to 10..
2. And the network_timeout setting is set as well..
3. But current decorator will use the new setting and ignore the old one, but we could improvise by changing the default timeout of all the websites other then those mentioned in the network_timeout i.e. the new setting to the value provided in timeout i.e. the old setting.

This way we used both the data as well as sent the user a warning to change the param ASAP without effectively losing some configuration setting.

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.

instead.

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review

if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText:
Before the changes,

Context lines are now displayed.

The printing of the patch was handled by print_beautified_diff . This function took difflib.unified_diff as its input.  But difflib.unified_diff had n=3 which is the default number of context lines that will be supplied.
The print_beautified_diff took care of printing the affected lines but it did not print the normal context lines.

comments.bodyText: @sladyn98 Tests fail, before making a PR just run pytest if you've made changes, and make sure that the coverage is 100%.
Yeah thats what we wanted to check actually @Makman2 and I had foreseen this :( now we need to make some modifications.

Okay now what I meant with considering all cases is that the bear might really refer to a line/column that doesn't exist. While line 1 column 1 is a valid position in an empty file, the bear might still pass a bad range (due to a bug or similar). That case has to be differentiated, otherwise user will get heavily confused.
E.g. if we have a file with 100KB but the bear points us to a location at line infinity, that's out of range, and not an empty file^^

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+Testing coala change on coala-bears
+===================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+There was an attempt to automate this through
+https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/4424 which used to depend upon docker
+image, but unfortunately the image breaks stuff for now.
+
+But we can still do it manually, by changing the coala dependency for the
+bears to be the one consisting of the changes made For which we need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, edit the requirements and run it on CI.
+
+Set-up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming we have already made changes to coala through a new branch, we can
+use the branch to install coala instead of master by editing requirements.txt
+file in coala-bears. So, lets set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these
+changes.
+
+If you have not already, clone your fork by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/coala-bears
+
+Make sure that you replace <your-username> with your corresponding github
+username.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch (other than master).
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    See `Git Tutorial <https://coala.io/gitbasics>`_ for more info.
+
+Now you've done that, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First thing we need is to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch <branch-name>, you
+can edit the coala dependency by changing the corresponding line to:
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+Set-up CI to run on your branch
+-------------------------------
+
+Since you need the tests to be ran on CI, set it up by modifying respective
+configuration files. You can have a look at our
+`CI Tutorial <https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Adding_CI.html>`_.
+for more info.
+
+For example, to run `travis-ci <https://travis-ci.org/>`_ on your
+branch you could modify .travis.yml file. At the end of the file, you'll find
+branch specification where you could white-list your branch name. So you should
+have the change as following:
+
+::
+
+    branches:
+      only:
+        - new_test_branch
+
+Simillarly, you can make changes to appveyor.yml file to run tests on AppveyorCI

@@ -0,0 +1,101 @@
+Testing changes to coala on coala-bears
+=======================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+You can do this by changing the coala dependency for the bears to
+be the one consisting of the changes. In order to do this, you need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, update the coala requirement to point to your
+changes and run CI on it.
+
+Set up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming you have already made changes to coala through a new branch, you can
+use that branch to install coala by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+Let's set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these changes:
+
+If you have not already, clone the coala-bears repository by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone -o upstream https://github.com/coala/coala-bears
+
+.. note::
+    ``-o upstream`` sets the remote name of the original coala-bears repository
+    as upstream.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+This tutorial assumes you are working on your own fork. To fork the repository,
+go to the official repository of coala-bears and click on the ``Fork``
+button from the website interface. To add it locally, simply run:
+
+::
+
+    $ git remote add myfork fork_link
+
+where ``myfork`` is the name of your fork, and ``fork_link`` is a link to your
+fork repository.
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch.
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+Here ``new_test_branch`` is the name of the new branch you created. You can
+use any name you want for this purpose.
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    Please go through our `Newcomers Guide <https://coala.io/newcomer>`_ if
+    you are new to coala.
+
+Now that you're on a new branch, you are free to make changes.
+

+-------------------------------------------
+
+First, you need to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now, assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch ``<branch-name>``,

@@ -0,0 +1,101 @@
+Testing changes to coala on coala-bears
+=======================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+You can do this by changing the coala dependency for the bears to
+be the one consisting of the changes. In order to do this, you need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, update the coala requirement to point to your
+changes and run CI on it.
+
+Set up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming you have already made changes to coala through a new branch, you can
+use that branch to install coala by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+Let's set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these changes:
+
+If you have not already, clone the coala-bears repository by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone -o upstream https://github.com/coala/coala-bears
+
+.. note::
+    ``-o upstream`` sets the remote name of the original coala-bears repository
+    as upstream.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+This tutorial assumes you are working on your own fork. To fork the repository,
+go to the official repository of coala-bears and click on the ``Fork``
+button from the website interface. To add it locally, simply run:
+
+::
+
+    $ git remote add myfork fork_link
+
+where ``myfork`` is the name of your fork, and ``fork_link`` is a link to your
+fork repository.
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch.
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+Here ``new_test_branch`` is the name of the new branch you created. You can
+use any name you want for this purpose.
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    Please go through our `Newcomers Guide <https://coala.io/newcomer>`_ if
+    you are new to coala.
+
+Now that you're on a new branch, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First, you need to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now, assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch ``<branch-name>``,
+you can edit the coala dependency by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+To do this, you need to edit the line in requirements.txt corresponding to:
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/coala/coala#egg=coala
+
+and change it to :
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+This will ensure that the coala will be installed using the source from the
+branch consisting of your changes to coala.
+
+Commit and push changes
+-----------------------
+
+You have now made the required changes to the bears repository, you are free
+to commit the changes and push the branch.

issue.title: coala_main.py: Changes Ctrl-Z to Ctrl-Z-Enter
issue.body:
Fixes #5254

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText: Ctrl-Z-Enter would look like we need to press all the 3 keys simultaneously. But iirc, The proper way to send an EOF signal in Windows is to press Ctrl-Z followed by Enter. So something like, Ctrl-Z followed by Enter would seem more appropriate.

@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ def do_nothing(*args):
 
 
 STR_ENTER_LETTER = 'Enter letter (Ctrl-{} to exit): '.format(
-    'Z' if platform.system() == 'Windows' else 'D')
+    'Z-Enter' if platform.system() == 'Windows' else 'D')

comments.bodyText: This is likely still a WIP and needs some work after a few reviews.
Added a test for autoapply_actions changes

I suspect this is a bad change. Here's an example of potentially unwanted behavior because of this change:
.coafile:
[python]
.
.
.
default_actions: **: ApplyPatchAction

With the above config, running coala --ci will still append ApplyPatchAction to the list of actions, therefore, it'll both show the patch and apply it. That's not desirable, right?
The AppVeyor CI is failing due to failed tests. Please check it @areebbeigh

The AppVeyor CI is failing due to failed tests. Please check it @areebbeigh

Before that I think I should confirm the above mentioned doubts.
(Ping @jayvdb )
I'm going to try and separate cli and config file actions. cli actions will override config (which was the case before this change).

As for AppVeyor timing out on coalaTest.py it actually passed the tests on my testing local branch.
That can probably be looked into after the changes are reviewed.

@akshatkarani if i delete this 8515861 commit. Would my PR gets deleted ?

It won't delete the PR, if you delete that commit.
You can delete that commit easily by using git interactive mode in terminal.
But, you need to squash your commits to one commit. Refer squashing section to know how to get into the interactive mode. Also, while you get into interactive mode, github provides some additional information on the terminal screen, please read those information carefully, as it will help you.
Also, use git commit --amend to add new local changes to your previous commit and then you can easily push this commit, without making an additional commits to the PR.

issue.title: coala_modes.py: Add a new mode to emit diff
issue.body:
This commit adds a new mode to coala. This mode will emit the patches obtained by the bears in unified diff format. To use this mode command is coala --diff. If the user wants to specify output file, --output can be used.
Closes #5379

issue.title: Python 3.4.3 support
issue.body:
Closes #5891
Sits on top of #5893

comments.bodyText: Why is 3.4.3 not here?

it would slow down all builds, unnecessarily.
We could add it to master builds.
Or I think we can also only run jobs on the nightly cron, which would reduce delays if multiple PRs are getting merged.

What is the benefit of using moban to copy async.py from https://github.com/NAStools/homeassistant/blob/master/homeassistant/util/async.py? That project seems to be out of maintenance.
Drawbacks I can see:

licence is not stated in async.py, but in this file.
async.py needs to be excluded in .coafile.
async.py has other functions, e.g. fire_coroutine_threadsafe, which we don't use.
We cannot easily test it.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -65,3 +67,6 @@ targets:
   - netlify.toml: docs/netlify.toml
   - .misc/appveyor.yml: ci/appveyor.yml.jj2
   - .misc/run_with_env.cmd: run_with_env.cmd
+copy:
+  # homeassistant license MIT
+  - coalib/misc/Asyncio.py: async.py

comments.bodyText:
The reason to do it this way is so that external code is 'managed'.  We can improve the way it is managed by improving moban.
Your point '3' is the only significant problem, and that can be solved by moban having patch support, so we can exclude the other code e.g. moremoban/moban#75 . A header can also be added using a patch.
I am not worried about the licensing being missing from the file, as anyone modifying this file will likely be informed via code review, or will be reverted when someone looks at the moban job.  We should distribute the MIT license, and any other license of code we're including, but by no means is this "substantial portions" according to the MIT license so we're not breaking the license by not including it.  And by having a control file which mentions where code came from, and thus were the license text can be found, we're not hiding the fact the code is copied.
The fact it is unmaintained is a problem for the future, as PRs upstream will not get merged.  Again, a .patch could solve that, but i would expect that this type of code would be moved to a new coala-compat package, or something like that, or a sub-module of coala-utils.
Same with the .coafile problems.  A patch can fix it.
The drawbacks of not doing it:

another piece of copied code will fade into the coala codebase and its history effectively lost
coala doesnt have a process for allowing externally written code into the repo.
moban doesnt have a user (coala) pushing for it to handle more complicated scenarios than just 'copy'.
coala doesnt start the process of identifying and fixing any existing copied code.  This one is MIT, but we will likely find some which isnt so freely licensed.  e.g. we have CC-BY-SA-licensed 'code' in some repos, and a major issue over in coala-quickstart
etc.

Being in .moban.yaml is an annoyance.  That is intentional ;-)
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -65,3 +67,6 @@ targets:
   - netlify.toml: docs/netlify.toml
   - .misc/appveyor.yml: ci/appveyor.yml.jj2
   - .misc/run_with_env.cmd: run_with_env.cmd
+copy:
+  # homeassistant license MIT
+  - coalib/misc/Asyncio.py: async.py

issue.title: coala/docs: Add position number convention
issue.body:
Added a note in Writing_Native_Bears.rst and a reminder
for developers in Writing_Linter_Bears.rst files.
Fixes #5297

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!
